items.text: Confirm any municipal EVSE requirements and EVEMS allowances. Typically in Parking or Zoning By-Laws. Examples at https://pluginbc.ca/policy/
items.details: Municipalities often require EV-ready or EV-capable parking and may allow load management (EVEMS). Checking local parking and zoning bylaws early ensures the electrical design can accommodate these requirements; the link in the item lists BC policy examples.

items.text: Confirm HVAC and domestic hot water approach with mech consultant (gas vs. electric) (distributed vs. centralized HVAC condensers)
items.details: Confirming heating, cooling, and domestic hot water approach (gas vs. electric; distributed vs. centralized) with the mechanical consultant ensures load calculations and service sizing are based on the correct assumptions.

items.text: Confirm fire pump requirements with mech consultant
items.details: Confirming fire pump requirements with the mechanical consultant ensures the electrical design allows for the correct supply, controls, and standby power per code.

items.text: Confirm any specialty equipment loads at high level for preliminary load calc (kitchen, IT, processing, etc.)
items.details: Identifying specialty loads (kitchens, IT, processing, etc.) at a high level allows them to be included in preliminary load calculations and avoids under-sizing the service.

items.text: Confirm potential CRU tenants with client and allocate loads for shell spaces (kitchen, data centre, food stores, etc.)
items.details: Locking in potential CRU tenant types and allocating loads for shell spaces (e.g. kitchen, data centre, food stores) ensures the base building electrical capacity is adequate.

items.text: Preliminary load calculations completed to determine service size and type from utility
items.details: Preliminary load calculations establish the required service size and type (voltage, number of feeds). Completing them early allows the utility application to proceed and avoids delays.

items.text: Preliminary generator load calculations completed
items.details: Generator load calculations determine standby capacity for life safety and optional loads. Complete them so that generator sizing and transfer schemes are correct.

items.text: Dwelling unit transformer calculations completed
items.details: Dwelling unit transformer calculations size the transformers that feed residential units. Completing them ensures compliance and avoids over- or under-sizing.

items.text: Lightning protection analysis has been conducted per CSA B72
items.details: A lightning protection analysis per CSA B72 determines whether a system is required and how it should be designed. Complete this so that the design meets the standard.

items.text: Review architectural drawings for changes. Rezoning or DP comments often lead to significant changes that can impact load calculations. Update load calc if required.
items.details: Rezoning or development permit comments often change building program or layout. Review architectural drawings for changes and update the load calculation if the changes affect loads.

items.text: Check architectural drawings to ensure all requested SD provisions have been incorporated (rooms, shafts, etc).
items.details: Ensure all electrical rooms, shafts, and other provisions identified at schematic design are still shown on the current architectural drawings so that the design can be developed correctly.

items.text: Procure preliminary motorlist from mechanical consultant. Update load calculation with information provided.
items.details: The mechanical consultant’s motor list drives a significant portion of the electrical load. Obtain it and update the load calculation so that service and distribution are accurately sized.

items.text: Coordinate with client to lock-in any decisions that affect loads (CRU tenant types, uses of amenity spaces, client equipment, etc.) Update load calc if required.
items.details: Locking in client decisions on CRU tenant types, amenity uses, and client equipment avoids late load changes and ensures the load calculation reflects the final design intent.

items.text: Load calculations are provided on drawings, major equipment load calcs have been peer reviewed
items.details: Including load calculations on the drawings and having major equipment load calcs peer reviewed ensures accuracy and provides a clear record for permit and construction.

items.text: Clearances from building to utility power lines confirmed. Consider additional clearance may be required so that construction workers are not within limits of approach (WorkSafe BC Req.)
items.details: Clearances from the building to utility lines must meet code (e.g. CEC Table 33). Consider additional clearance so that construction workers remain outside limits of approach per WorkSafe BC. Refer to CEC 2021, Article Table 33.

items.text: Clearances from building to utilty pole transformers confirmed.
items.details: Clearances from the building to utility pole transformers must meet code (e.g. CEC 26-012). Verify distances so that safety and utility access are maintained. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 26-012(1).

items.text: Survey drawing and land title procured by Owner and reviewed to confirm no statutory rights-of-way are on the property for existing utility services.
items.details: Reviewing the survey and land title confirms whether statutory rights-of-way for existing utilities affect the site. The owner typically provides these; the electrical design must respect ROWs.

items.text: ESI form filled out (service application form), submitted to utility with SLD and arch plans
items.details: The ESI (service application) form, single-line diagram, and architectural plans are submitted to the utility to initiate the service design. Submit early to avoid delays.

items.text: Vista switch requirements confirmed by utility
items.details: Vista switch (or similar utility-owned switching) requirements are set by the utility for high-voltage or complex services. Confirm so that the single-line diagram and specs are correct.

items.text: Location of available power service confirmed by utility (which street / frontage)
items.details: Confirm with the utility which street or frontage will supply power so that service entrance location and site layout can be coordinated.

items.text: Utility equipment pad / chamber / kiosk locations confirmed with utility
items.details: Pad-, chamber-, or kiosk-mounted utility equipment must be located per utility requirements. Confirm locations so that site and civil drawings can be coordinated.

items.text: Utility ROWs are clear of other structures and services. No structure above or below ROW areas when required by utility.
items.details: Utility rights-of-way must remain clear of other structures and services as required by the utility. Verify so that the design does not conflict with ROW conditions.

items.text: Location of electrical service equipment as close as possible to service entrance
items.details: Locating service equipment as close as practicable to the service entrance minimizes conductor length and cost and aligns with code (e.g. CEC 6-206). Refer to CEC 2021, Article 6-206(c).

items.text: Location of electrical service equipment is above flood elevation
items.details: Service equipment must be above flood elevation where required by code or authority. Verify elevation so that equipment is not at risk of flooding. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 6-206(c)(v).

items.text: Access to and location of utility service rooms and rooms containing metering equipment comply with utility requirements
items.details: Access and location of utility service rooms and metering rooms must comply with utility requirements. Confirm so that layout and access are acceptable to the utility.

items.text: Submit a revised service application (ESI Form) to the utility if updated load calc shows an increase from the SD application. Reconfirm vista switch requirements if applicable.
items.details: The ESI (service application) form, single-line diagram, and architectural plans are submitted to the utility to initiate the service design. Submit early to avoid delays.

items.text: Revenue meters conform to utility requirements (locations, clearances, meter bases, CT/PT compartments & conduit details, sealing provisions, comm provisions)
items.details: Revenue meter locations, clearances, meter bases, CT/PT compartments, conduit, sealing, and communications must conform to utility standards. Confirm details with the utility.

items.text: Confirm size and quantity of incoming service ducts with utility
items.details: Confirm the size and number of incoming service ducts with the utility so that duct bank and service entrance design match utility expectations.

items.text: Send utility service entrance duct profile, site plan, and service room layout for initial review and comments
items.details: Sending the duct profile, site plan, and service room layout for utility review allows early feedback and avoids rework at contract documents.

items.text: Make formal service application to utility
items.details: The ESI (service application) form, single-line diagram, and architectural plans are submitted to the utility to initiate the service design. Submit early to avoid delays.

items.text: North arrows shown on plans, not shown on schematics / details
items.details: North arrows belong on plan views (e.g. floor plans, site) to orient the reader; they are not shown on schematics or detail sheets.

items.text: Company logos and disclaimer shown, no frames around logos, reflects current AES office locations
items.details: Drawings should show current company logos and disclaimers without decorative frames, and reflect current AES office locations for consistency and liability.

items.text: Room names and room numbers shown
items.details: Room names and numbers help coordinate across disciplines and with the architect. Ensure they match the architectural drawing set.

items.text: Drawing titles, subtitles, and discipline shown
items.details: Drawing titles, subtitles, and discipline (e.g. Electrical) identify each sheet. Use a consistent format that matches the project’s drawing standards.

items.text: Drawing notes are project-specific, coordinated with design
items.details: Notes must be specific to the project and coordinated with the design. Avoid generic notes that do not apply or conflict with the design.

items.text: Scale bars shown (plot independent), original sheet size marked
items.details: Scale bars should be plot-independent where possible, and the original sheet size should be marked so that scaling is clear when sheets are printed or referenced.

items.text: Title block and sheet size matches architectural
items.details: The electrical title block and sheet size should match the architectural set so that the combined drawing package is consistent.

items.text: Drawing numbering format matches architectural
items.details: Use the same drawing numbering format as the architect so that cross-references and sheet order are consistent across the package.

items.text: Symbol schedule includes all symbols, matches all drawings
items.details: The symbol schedule must list every symbol used on the drawings and must match the symbols actually shown so that readers can interpret the drawings correctly.

items.text: Drawing list includes all drawings, matches all drawings
items.details: The drawing list must include every sheet in the set and match the actual drawings so that the package is complete and easy to navigate.

items.text: Energy code compliance statement
items.details: Include the required energy code compliance statement so that the drawings clearly state how the design meets the energy code.

items.text: Statement of compliance with code consultant's report and/or alternate solutions summary
items.details: Where a code consultant’s report or alternate solutions apply, the drawings should include a statement of compliance so that the authority and contractors see the link to the report.

items.text: Utility equipment pad / chamber / kiosk locations shown. Indicate dimensions of all clearances and ROW areas.
items.details: Show pad, chamber, and kiosk locations with dimensions and ROW areas so that site and civil coordination is clear.

items.text: Utility service duct routing shown. Ducts are to utility standards for size, quantity, number of bends, etc.
items.details: Show duct routing to utility standards (size, quantity, bends, etc.) so that the duct bank can be built and accepted by the utility.

items.text: T-drains indicated for all utility ducts before entering building.
items.details: T-drains at duct entries prevent water from following ducts into the building. Indicate them at all utility duct entries.

items.text: Service entrance duct profile detailed.
items.details: Sending the duct profile, site plan, and service room layout for utility review allows early feedback and avoids rework at contract documents.

items.text: Service ducts indicated as concrete encased for any portion run inside the building
items.details: Any portion of service ducts run inside the building is typically required to be concrete encased. Indicate this on the drawings. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 6-208(1)(a).

items.text: All HV ducts indicated as RGS where run inside building
items.details: High-voltage ducts run inside the building should be shown as rigid galvanized steel (RGS) per code and utility requirements. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 36-100(2).

items.text: Electrical service and comm entrance facility room locations shown
items.details: Show the locations of the electrical and communications entrance facility rooms so that the architect and other disciplines can coordinate access and space.

items.text: Existing services shown
items.details: Show existing services that remain, are abandoned, or are relocated so that phasing and demolition are clear.

items.text: Phasing shown, circuits maintained / replaced where affected by demolition or relocation.  Temporary provisions detailed.
items.details: Indicate phasing: which circuits are maintained, replaced, or relocated, and any temporary provisions, so that construction and shutdowns can be planned.

items.text: Provisions for future expansions shown.
items.details: Show provisions for future expansion (spare conduits, capacity, spaces) so that future work can be done without major modifications.

items.text: Utility equipment pad / chamber / kiosk grounding details complete. Connections to building rebar and exposed metal parts indicated and project specific.
items.details: Detail grounding for pads, chambers, and kiosks: connections to building rebar and exposed metal, and make details project-specific so that grounding is buildable.

items.text: All sections of ductbanks detailed (depth, spacing, etc., including lighting and signage ducts, pullboxes, manholes)
items.details: Detail all duct bank sections (depth, spacing, pull boxes, manholes, lighting and signage ducts) so that civil and electrical construction are coordinated.

items.text: Concrete encasement of ductbanks indicated (if applicable)
items.details: Where required, indicate concrete encasement of duct banks so that civil scope and structural implications are clear.

items.text: Pull boxes indicated for long duct runs or runs with multiple bends. Use of pull boxes approved by utilities.
items.details: Pull boxes ease cable installation on long or multi-bend runs. Show them where needed and confirm that their use is acceptable to the utility.

items.text: Engine block heater receptacles shown (cold regions only), IPLC or similar energy controls specified
items.details: In cold regions, show engine block heater receptacles and specify IPLC or similar energy controls so that vehicle heating does not unnecessarily increase demand.

items.text: Electric vehicle supply equipment locations shown
items.details: Show EVSE locations and any load management (EVEMS) so that the design meets municipal and energy code requirements and is buildable.

items.text: Power for building signage
items.details: Indicate power for building signage so that the architect and signage contractor have a clear scope and location.

items.text: Light pole base detailed
items.details: Detail the light pole base (anchor bolts, concrete, access) so that structural and civil coordination is complete.

items.text: Bollard base detailed (lighting or EVSE)
items.details: Detail bollard bases for lighting or EVSE so that foundations and mounting are buildable.

items.text: Parking gate / kiosk pedestal base detailed
items.details: Detail the parking gate or kiosk pedestal base so that structural and electrical scope are clear.

items.text: Weatherproof enclosures detailed (also check other floor plan sheets where exterior devices are indicated)
items.details: Detail weatherproof enclosures for exterior devices on this and other sheets so that equipment is suitable for the environment.

items.text: Drawings are coordinated with mech, arch, civil, landscape plans (device locations, physical conflicts, phasing conflicts)
items.details: Coordinate device locations and phasing with mechanical, architectural, civil, and landscape so that there are no physical or phasing conflicts.

items.text: Confirm with client if separate common area meters are required for different occupancies in mixed-use buildings (eg. separate commercial and residential common area meters)
items.details: In mixed-use buildings, the client or utility may require separate common area meters per occupancy (e.g. commercial vs. residential). Confirm with the client so that metering matches the billing structure.

items.text: Provide separate utility revenue meters for house loads, each dwelling unit, each CRU, EVSE distribution, Fire Pumps
items.details: Revenue meter locations, clearances, meter bases, CT/PT compartments, conduit, sealing, and communications must conform to utility standards. Confirm details with the utility.

items.text: No utility revenue meters are downstream of other utillity revenue meters
items.details: Revenue meter locations, clearances, meter bases, CT/PT compartments, conduit, sealing, and communications must conform to utility standards. Confirm details with the utility.

items.text: Temporary master revenue meters are provided where required (upstream of all utility revenue meters)
items.details: Revenue meter locations, clearances, meter bases, CT/PT compartments, conduit, sealing, and communications must conform to utility standards. Confirm details with the utility.

items.text: Information metering shown, if required by Energy Code or Client request
items.details: Information metering (non-revenue) may be required by the energy code or client. Show it on the single-line diagram where required.

items.text: Generator size indicated
items.details: Show the generator size (kW/kVA) on the single-line diagram so that the emergency system capacity is clear.

items.text: Fully rated 100% generator load bank test breaker provided, accessible load bank connection terminals
items.details: A fully rated 100% load bank test breaker with accessible connection terminals allows testing of the generator at full load. Show it connected per manufacturer and code.

items.text: Generator load bank breaker connected directly to the emergency generator (ie. Load bank breaker is not downstream of the main generator breaker)
items.details: The load bank breaker must be connected directly to the generator (not downstream of the main generator breaker) so that load bank testing is possible without backfeed issues. Refer to CSA C282-19, Article 8.7.2.(d).

items.text: Separate transfer switches for life safety and non-life-safety emergency distribution (or vital / delayed vital / conditional in a healthcare facility)
items.details: Use separate transfer switches for life safety vs. non-life-safety (or vital/delayed/conditional in healthcare) so that load priority and code requirements are met. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 46-108(5).

items.text: Outdoor Generators: 208V/1PH connection shown to generator for integral panel that feeds coolant heaters, battery charger, maintenance receptacles (confirm size with manufacturer)
items.details: For outdoor generators, show a 208V single-phase connection for the integral panel that feeds coolant heaters, battery charger, and maintenance receptacles; confirm size with the manufacturer.

items.text: Parallel Generators: Means to automatically reduce load in the event of a single generator failure provided to ensure continuation of emergency power. (multiple transfer switches)
items.details: With parallel generators, provide means to automatically reduce load on generator failure so that the remaining generator(s) can continue to supply emergency power (e.g. multiple transfer switches). Refer to CSA C282-19, Article 6.9.1.

items.text: Fire pump normal power supply has no breakers or disconnect devices between the FP breaker and the service box (ie. FP breaker is not downstream of the main service breaker)
items.details: There must be no breakers or disconnects between the fire pump breaker and the service box (i.e. the FP breaker is not downstream of the main service breaker) so that fire pump supply is reliable. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 32-306(1)(a).

items.text: Fire pump emergency breaker connected directly to the emergency generator (ie. FP breaker is not downstream of the main generator breaker)
items.details: The fire pump emergency breaker must be connected directly to the emergency generator (not downstream of the main generator breaker) so that the fire pump has a dedicated emergency supply. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 32-306(6).

items.text: Fire pump uses separate ATS. FP and ATS noted as supplied by mechanical
items.details: The fire pump uses its own ATS. The fire pump and ATS are typically supplied by the mechanical contractor; note this on the drawings. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 32-308.

items.text: Ground fault protection on circuits of solidly grounded systems rated at and greater than 2000A (208V) and 1000A (600V)
items.details: Ground fault protection is required on solidly grounded systems at 2000 A and above (208 V) and 1000 A and above (600 V). Show GFP devices on the single-line diagram. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 14-102(1).

items.text: Ground fault detection for all ungrounded/impedance grounded systems
items.details:
Ungrounded or impedance-grounded systems require ground fault detection. Show detection means on the single-line diagram so that the system can be monitored. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 10-302
10-400.

items.text: System neutrals grounded at the correct locations, single point per system: service box, generator X0, transformer X0, first switch or tie point
items.details:
Neutrals must be grounded at a single point per system: typically at the service box, generator X0, transformer X0, or first tie. Verify so that parallel neutral paths and stray currents are avoided. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 10-210
10-212.

items.text: Systems with multiple sources use either 3-wire distribution / 3-pole ATS or 4-wire / 4-pole ATS & main-tie-mains (separately derived); any other 4-wire system types (i.e. commonly derived) must carefully consider parallel neutral/ground return paths to avoid stray currents / ground fault detection problems
items.details:
Multi-source systems use either 3-wire distribution with 3-pole ATS or 4-wire with 4-pole ATS and main-tie-main (separately derived). Other 4-wire arrangements require care to avoid parallel neutral/ground paths and ground fault issues. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 10-212(1)(c)
Figure B10-9.

items.text: Grounding detail provided. Ground bus on detail shown connected at service box.
items.details: Provide a grounding detail with the ground bus connected at the service box so that installation and inspection are clear.

items.text: All circuit breaker and fuse sizes shown (frame, trip, LI/LSI/LSIG, 100% ratings as required).  LSI/LSIG breakers recommended for feeders over 400A.
items.details: Show all breaker and fuse sizes (frame, trip, LI/LSI/LSIG, 100% ratings as required). LSI/LSIG are recommended for feeders over 400 A for better protection.

items.text: Fire pump breaker / wire sizing is correct, typically 600% FLA utility side, 300% FLA gen side breakers, breakers labeled and lockable, will not trip before breaker in fire pump controller.  FLA, breaker sizing, and tripping coordination to be confirmed based on fire pump shop drawings.
items.details: Fire pump breaker and conductor sizing must be correct (e.g. 600% FLA utility side, 300% FLA gen side); breakers must be labeled and lockable and must not trip before the breaker in the fire pump controller. Confirm with fire pump shop drawings. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 32-306.

items.text: Selective coordination of protective devices specified where required
items.details:
Where required by code, specify selective coordination of protective devices so that a fault clears at the nearest device without upstream trips. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 24-302(4)
38-062
46-208
58-306.

items.text: All conduit, wire and bus sizes shown, conductor ampacity matches protective devices, 3-wire vs. 4-wire indicated, bonding wires indicated
items.details: Show all conduit, wire, and bus sizes; ensure conductor ampacity matches protective devices; indicate 3-wire vs. 4-wire and bonding conductors so that the installation is buildable and compliant.

items.text: A neutral conductor is provided to all in-line meter bases (≤ 200A), including those serving 3-phase, 3-wire loads (BCH Secondary Metering Guide requirement)
items.details: A neutral must be provided to all in-line meter bases 200 A and below, including those serving 3-phase 3-wire loads, per the BCH Secondary Metering Guide.

items.text: Interrupting capacity of o/c devices shown, available fault current calculation is provided, consistent with specs and panel schedules
items.details: Show interrupting capacity of overcurrent devices and provide an available fault current calculation so that equipment is applied within its rating; keep consistent with specs and panel schedules. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 14-012.

items.text: Series-rated combinations clearly identified if used, with permanent labels
items.details: Where series-rated combinations are used, clearly identify them and specify permanent labels so that replacement and maintenance use the correct breakers. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 14-014.

items.text: All equipment designations and locations shown (including LV relay panels, meter cabinets, etc.)
items.details: Show all equipment designations and locations, including LV relay panels and meter cabinets, so that the single-line diagram is a complete reference.

items.text: Power conditioning or surge protection shown
items.details: Show power conditioning or surge protection where specified so that the design intent is clear.

items.text: Transformer sizes shown
items.details: Show transformer kVA ratings on the single-line diagram so that distribution capacity is clear.

items.text: K-Ratings of transformers indicated, if applicable
items.details: Where K-rated transformers are used (e.g. for nonlinear loads), indicate the K-rating so that the correct transformer is specified.

items.text: Future spares or spaces indicated
items.details: Indicate future spares or spaces so that panel and switchgear layout allow for expansion.

items.text: Key interlocks shown, sequence of operations description correct, match utility requirements
items.details: Show key interlocks and ensure the sequence of operations matches utility and design requirements so that paralleling and transfer are safe and correct.

items.text: Protection (fire / circuit integrity rating) of emergency conductors is specified
items.details: Specify the fire or circuit integrity rating of emergency conductors so that life safety circuits meet code for fire resistance. Refer to NBC 2020, Article 3.2.7.10.

items.text: Wires and cables selected using 75 Deg C ampacity
items.details:
Size wires and cables using 75 °C ampacity unless otherwise required so that ampacity is in accordance with the CEC. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 4-006
Tables 2 & 4.

items.text: Underground wires and cables derated as required
items.details:
Apply the required derating to underground conductors so that ampacity is correct for the installation conditions. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 4-004(d)
Tables D8 - D11B
IEEE 835.

items.text: No unrelated equipment in HV equipment rooms (e.g. FACP, piping, mech or comm equipment)
items.details: HV equipment rooms should contain only HV-related equipment. Do not locate FACP, piping, mechanical, or communications equipment in the same room so that access and safety are maintained.

items.text: HV equipment rooms not located below living space where possible. If unavoidable, confirm acoustic considerations with architect and coordinate drains to not run through room.
items.details: Where possible, avoid locating HV equipment rooms below living space. If unavoidable, coordinate with the architect on acoustics and ensure drains do not run through the room.

items.text: Generator rooms not located below living space where possible. If unavoidable, confirm acoustic considerations with architect.
items.details: Where possible, avoid locating generator rooms below living space. If unavoidable, coordinate with the architect on acoustics.

items.text: Generator fuel / exhaust / ventilation requirements coordinated with arch and mech
items.details: Coordinate generator fuel, exhaust, and ventilation with the architect and mechanical engineer so that code and manufacturer requirements are met.

items.text: Generator fuel tanks sized to C282, Z32, and NFPA 20 requirements (8-hours for fire pumps per NFPA 20 Article 9.6.2.3)
items.details: Size generator fuel tanks per CSA C282, Z32, and NFPA 20. For fire pump applications, NFPA 20 Article 9.6.2.3 requires 8 hours of fuel. Refer to CSA C282-19.

items.text: Generator Room is located above the flood elevation
items.details: Locate the generator room above flood elevation so that emergency power is available during flooding events. Refer to CSA C282-19.

items.text: Generator is located within 1 storey of grade where required in accordance with CSA Z32 (health care facilities).
items.details: For healthcare facilities, CSA Z32 may require the generator to be within one storey of grade. Verify and comply so that fuel delivery and maintenance are feasible. Refer to CSA C282-19, Article 6.2.2.

items.text: Sub-Electrical and Communication Rooms are located above the flood elevation if required by municipal by-laws
items.details: Where required by municipal by-laws, locate sub-electrical and communication rooms above flood elevation.

items.text: Future replacement of large equipment (unit subs, generators) has been considered in locating service rooms.
items.details: Consider how large equipment (unit subs, generators) will be replaced when locating service rooms so that access and rigging are possible.

items.text: Electrical and Communications service rooms sized. Markups of locations, dimensions, and fire ratings sent to architect for coordination.
items.details: Size electrical and communications rooms and send markups (locations, dimensions, fire ratings) to the architect for coordination so that space is adequate.

items.text: Routing of major electrical and communication feeders planned. Shafts and riser spaces marked up and sent to architect for coordination.
items.details: Plan routing of major electrical and communication feeders; mark up shafts and riser spaces and send to the architect so that vertical and horizontal runs are feasible.

items.text: Generator room is 2hr rated and contains only equipment related to the emergency power supply system.
items.details: The generator room must be 2-hour fire rated and contain only equipment related to the emergency power supply system so that the emergency source is protected. Refer to NBC 2020, Article 3.6.2.8.(1).

items.text: Generator has 1m clearance on all sides except the exhaust air duct end.
items.details: Maintain at least 1 m clearance on all sides of the generator except the exhaust end so that maintenance and cooling are possible. Refer to CSA C-282-19, Article 6.5.1.1.

items.text: If multiple generators are in the same room, required 1m clearances of each generator do not overlap.
items.details: When multiple generators share a room, ensure the required 1 m clearances around each unit do not overlap so that access and cooling are adequate. Refer to CSA C-282-19, Article 6.5.2.

items.text: Clearances around electrical equipment (1m min.)
items.details: Maintain minimum 1 m clearance around electrical equipment so that access for operation and maintenance is safe and code-compliant. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 2-308(1).

items.text: Clearances around electrical equipment increased to 1.5m min. when there is only one exit path and equipment is rated 1200A or more, or over 750V.
items.details: Where there is only one exit path and equipment is 1200 A or more or over 750 V, increase clearance to at least 1.5 m so that egress and safety are adequate. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 2-310(2).

items.text: HV station ground electrode / ground mat / adjacent metal bonding detailed, step and touch calculations provided, ground testing scope specified
items.details: Detail the HV station ground electrode, ground mat, and bonding to adjacent metal; provide step and touch calculations and specify ground testing scope so that the installation is safe. Refer to CEC 2021, Article 36-300 to 36-312.

items.text: Visible and/or remote disconnection means for all HV sources of supply
items.details: Provide visible and/or remote disconnection means for all HV sources so that the installation can be safely isolated (e.g. CEC 36-214). Refer to CEC 2021, Article 36-214.

items.text: Emergency battery pack in the generator and emergency switchgear rooms (50 Lx for 2 h)
items.details: Provide emergency battery pack lighting in generator and emergency switchgear rooms (50 lx for 2 h) per CSA C282 so that maintenance and egress are safe. Refer to CSA C282-19, Article 6.11.1.

items.text: Convenience outlets shown in all service rooms and elec/comm riser closets
items.details: Show convenience outlets in all service rooms and electrical/communication riser closets so that maintenance and testing have power.

items.text: Housekeeping pads
items.details: Show housekeeping pads for equipment that requires them so that structural and electrical scope are clear.

items.text: Photocell and timer for exterior lighting control
items.details: Provide photocell and/or timer control for exterior lighting so that lights operate only when needed and energy code requirements are met.

items.text: Check voltage drop to exterior fixtures
items.details: Check voltage drop to exterior fixtures so that light output and lamp life are acceptable at the end of the run.

items.text: Luminaire mounting compatible with ceiling type
items.details: Ensure luminaire mounting is compatible with the ceiling type (e.g. suspended, concrete, insulated) so that installation is feasible and code-compliant.

items.text: Fixture types indicated and included on schedules
items.details: Indicate fixture types on the drawings and include them on the fixture schedule so that procurement and installation are clear.

items.text: Exit Signs are required
items.details:
Exit signs are required per NBC. Verify that all required locations are shown and that the type (e.g. running man) meets the authority having jurisdiction. Refer to NBC 2020, Article 3.4.5.1.(1)
9.9.11.3.(1).

items.text: Directional exits provided where required
items.details:
